SiteVariableDescription: Soil stability test: provides information about the degree of soil structural development and erosion resistance when exposed to rapid wetting. Sites with average values of 5.5 or above generally are very resistant to erosion. Maximum possible soil stability values may be less than 6 for very coarse sandy soils. High values usually reflect good hydrologic function.
Units: classes: 1 is assigned to peds which dissolve within 5 seconds, 2 if between 5-30 seconds, 3 if between 30-300 seconds, 4 if 10-25% of the ped remain after the dipping cycle, 5 if 25-75% remain, and 6 if >75% of the ped remain intact.
ControlledUnits: Stability classes are assigned from 1-6: class of 1 is assigned to peds which dissolve within 5 seconds, 2 if between 5-30 seconds, 3 if between 30-300 seconds, 4 if 10-25% of the ped remain after the dipping cycle, 5 if 25-75% remain, and 6 if >75% of the ped remain intact.
Comments: Method developed by JER team. Herrick et al., 2017. . Monitoring manual for grassland, shurbland, and savanna ecosystems. USDA - ARS Jornada Experimental Range.; WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Pedoderm class: describes the type of material that occurs at the air-soil interface--the 'pedoderm' or upper 3 cm of the soil surface.
Units: Categorical variable: bare single grain soil < weak physical or biological crust < strong physical crust < erosion pavement < desert pavement.
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Resource Retention Class: classifies the spatial pattern of persistent vascular plants and interpatches that govern resource movement and erosion rates.
Units: Ordinal variable: 1. Interconnected persistent plant cover or dense bunchgrasses and surrounding round interpatch areas <30 cm, 2. Persistent plants interconnected and surrounding round/oval interpatch areas >30 cm, 3. Persistent plant patches fragmented by elongated interpatch areas that are bounded in the plot, 4. Persistent plant patches fragmented by elongated interpatch areas that cross through the plot, 5. Interpatch areas interconnected and crossing the plot in several directions; isolated persistent plant patches. 6. Interpatch areas interconnected; scattered or no persistent plants.
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Soil redistribution class: uses several surface features, such as pedestals and depositional mounds, to classify the spatial extent and severity of erosion and deposition.
Units: Ordinal variable: 0. No evidence of erosion or deposition, 2. Patchy, slight (typically 1-5 cm) soil loss and deposition, 3a. Extensive, moderate soil loss (1-10 cm), 3b. Extensive, moderate soil deposition (1-10 cm), 4a. Extensive, severe erosion (>10 cm); little deposition, 4b. Extensive, severe erosion (>10 cm) with patchy sediment deposition, 4c. Extensive, severe sediment deposition (>10 cm).
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Soil pit characterization: define the soil profile based on identification of various soil horizons. Horizons are delineated by soil texture, color, chemical and mineral content, thickness, and structure.
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Landforms: define the recognizable and distinctive general surface of the land. Landforms, as three-dimensional surfaces, generally have a consistent position with respect to surrounding landforms and have some significance to people. Landforms can indicate soil patterns.
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Slope shape: Slope shape describes the contour of the land using Linear, Concave, and Convex. The description describes both the downslope direction (with the aspect) and slope shape perpendicular to the aspect (or along the contour)
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Soil stability test: provides information about the degree of soil structural development and erosion resistance when exposed to rapid wetting. Sites with average values of 5.5 or above generally are very resistant to erosion. Maximum possible soil stability values may be less than 6 for very coarse sandy soils. High values usually reflect good hydrologic function.
Units: classes: 1 is assigned to peds which dissolve within 5 seconds, 2 if between 5-30 seconds, 3 if between 30-300 seconds, 4 if 10-25% of the ped remain after the dipping cycle, 5 if 25-75% remain, and 6 if >75% of the ped remain intact.
Comments: WO - no category

SiteVariableDescription: Oven dry weight: Difference in soil weight in situ and oven dried to determine moisture content.
